contextId.information: Since this song is addressed to Yahweh, Yahweh can be referred to as "you." AT: " Yahweh, I will give thanks to you with all my heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: I will give thanks to Yahweh with my whole heart

contextId.information: David calls himself "your servant" when speaking to God as a sign of respect. AT: "I am warned"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The king is speaking about himself in the third person. This can be stated in first person. AT: "me, his anointed one ... answer me ... rescue me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: his anointed one ... answer him ... rescue him

contextId.information: Here God refers to himself. AT: "Offer to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Here God is still speaking and speaks of himself in the third person. AT: "But to the wicked I say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: But to the wicked God says

contextId.information: Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "who hate me ... before me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The writer refers to himself as "your servant." AT: "to me, your servant" or "to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The writer refers to himself as "your servant." AT: "me, your servant" or "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The writer refers to himself as "your servant." AT: "must I, your servant" or "must I" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The writer speaks about himself as "your servant." AT: "Guarantee my welfare" or "Help and protect me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: Guarantee the welfare of your servant
